I was raised in a catholic household, one of several children. Although my mother supports the right to choose, she obviously never considered her own circumstances to warrant it. I disagreed. I was vehemently against abortion... as a child. As an adult I have converted to buddhism, seeing it as the only religion that not only wants it's followers to think for themselves, but to understand what it is that makes them think that way at all...
 As I grew up and since I have often been around children, and I love them very much. But I have seen firsthand the difference between a child who has been wanted, loved, and nurtured, and those that are seen as a burden, or worse. Who am I to sentence an unwanted child to a life of abuse and neglect? I beleive that we have the responsibility not only to protect life, but to protect a person's quality of life. Millions of children around the world are suffering... I would like to see to them before I worry about a child that isn't even born.
 When I grew up I found out that life is never cut and dry. I realized that people are often faced with horrible decisions, placed in dangerous predicaments, saddled with unimaginable medical problems, etc.
 I could no longer sit back comfortably in my easy chair judging people for these decisions.
 Someone mentioned the guilt some women feel after having an abortion, this is understandable, it is a huge decision and a huge loss. Most women I know who have had the procedure regret not their decision, but the circumstances that made their decision for them. Most women would not have chosen abortion if matters of their life had been more welcoming to the idea. And most people who support abortion, or I should say, a woman's right to abortion, would never undergo the procedure themselves.
 People who had the children have regrets as well. I don't know a single parent who doesn't feel guilt about something concerning their child.
 
 Basically, I grew up to realize that life is tough, and everyone struggles. As Americans I believe we were endowed with not only the right to decide our own future, but with the responsiblity of ensuring those rights for future generations.
